addressleaf.section:
To my L. T
re
r 16 N
o
1592

page.lettertext:
fol.363r
1592 16 Novem
b
To my L. Trea
s
May it please yo
r
good L. Heere is litle other
mater to be written unto yo
w
, then that w
ch
hath
already bin signified in my former. This
Councel
and
Count Maurice
have bin earnest w
t
the states, to intreat her
Ma
tie
by letter,
at after a
certaine time
e companies appointed for
e service of
Britaine
, may be sent backe againe. W
at
course
will be taken, I can not understand. For though
the motion at first was flatly rejected, yet sins
it hath bin urged in more vehement maner. And
w
at
reason they might have, not to sue unto her Hig
es
for continuance of her succo
rs
, I can not otherwise
conjecture, then I noted to yo
r
L.
e 10 of Oc
t
.
For these are maters debated in their secret assem-
blies, and not imparted unto me, but by suche meanes
of privat frindes, as are not offred very often.
For
e Convoy of their shippes,
at are gone
for
Bourdeaulx
, it was resolved of late,
at there
should be 4 shippes of warre armed out of
Zeland
,
and 6 out of
Holland
w
t
2 monethes victuals
. The Hollanders were
unready, when
e winde came about: for whiche
e
Marchants sette saile about 8 daies agoe, and were
onely accompanied w
t
e forsaid shippes of Zeland
The 6 shippes of Holland are nowe in a readines: [and]
because they are furnished w
t
2 monethes
victuals
provisi[on it]
is meant they shall be sent to
e coast of France [to]
attend
e returne of their Marchants from Bour[deaulx]
and in
e meane time, to doe suche service to
e
K[ing]
as his occasions may require. I am also in [some]
hope,
at
where
at
e
end of
2 monethes
victuals are ex[.]
for w
ch
time they are stoared, they shall be
further releived
longer
after
contiued
up
o
e self same course
and c
o
tinued there still
to w
ch
effect I have also dealt w
t
d[ivers in privat]
whome I find well [inclined .]
From
e Hage 16 N
o
1592
Yo
r
L. most humbly boud en Tho. Bodley
